metadata.title: Inactivation of SARS-CoV-2 in chlorinated swimming pool water

abstract.text: SARS-CoV-2 transmission remains a global problem which exerts a significant direct cost to public 7 health. Additionally, other aspects of physical and mental health can be affected by limited access to 8 social and exercise venues as a result of lockdowns in the community or personal reluctance due to 9 safety concerns. Swimming pools have reopened in the UK as of April 12 th , but the effect of swimming 10 pool water on inactivation of SARS-CoV-2 has not yet been directly demonstrated. Here we 11 demonstrate that water which adheres to UK swimming pool guidelines is sufficient to reduce SARS-12
CoV-2 infectious titre by at least 3 orders of magnitude. 13

body_text.text: SARS-CoV-2, the causative agent of the COVID-19 pandemic, continues to transmit globally and makes 15 quantifying the risks involved in different settings of great importance as societies attempt to return 16 to normal. The potential for waterborne transmission of SARS-CoV-2 in the context of public swimming 17 pools has not yet been investigated. Outbreaks of respiratory viruses such as adenoviruses, and 18 enteric viruses such as enteroviruses, Hepatitis A and noroviruses which can transmit by the faecal-19 oral route are sometimes linked to swimming pools but often owe to improper maintenance of 20 chlorine levels (Bonadonna & La Rosa, 2019; WHO, 2000) . In the UK, swimming pools are treated with 21 sodium hypochlorite to maintain a free chlorine level of 1.5-3 mg/l (ppm). The pH is also adjusted to 22 between 7.0 and 7.6 as the availability of active free chlorine decreases with increasing pH (PWTAG, 23 2020). Here, by treating SARS-CoV-2 with swimming pool water which conforms to UK guidelines we 24 demonstrate at least a 3-log10 reduction in infectious titre.

Virus stocks of SARS-CoV-2 for use in infectivity assays are generally generated by infection of a 28 permissive cell line such as Vero and harvesting of virus in highly buffered cell culture medium. 29

body_text.text: However, we observed in preliminary experiments that even a small amount of buffered medium was 30 able to quench the chlorine activity of water samples whereas with an unbuffered saline solution the 31 quenching was largely mitigated (not shown). The buffering capacity of the virus stock itself in cell 32 culture medium would make it difficult to observe inactivation at the desired free chlorine and pH 33 levels during testing. By infecting Caco-2 and Vero cells with a SARS-CoV-2 B.1 lineage virus at a 34 multiplicity of 0.01pfu/cell, extensively washing off and replacing the growth medium with saline 35 solution 24 hours before harvest at 3 days post-infection, we were able to generate stocks of infectious 36 virus with reduced buffering capacity. To further minimise the effect of the non-viral constituents of 37 the stock, such as cellular components which would exert a chlorine demand on the water samples 38 tested, a 1:100 dilution of virus in normal saline was used in all inactivation tests. 39
body_text.section: Generating SARS-CoV-2 virus stocks suitable for inactivation testing 27

body_text.text: Water was collected from swimming pools in volumes of up to 1 litre and transported to the laboratory 41 on the same day. The water was tested for free chlorine and pH levels upon arrival at the laboratory 42 and adjusted to a range of values. A 1:100 dilution of SARS-CoV-2 virus stock generated in Caco-2 cells 43 was then added to duplicate water samples in a total volume of 1 ml, incubated for 30 seconds at RT 44 before quenching the chlorine with a one-tenth volume of 10X cell culture medium. Residual virus 45 infectivity in the samples was then titrated on Vero cells by TCID50 assay. In each experiment the same 46 virus stock was incubated for 30 seconds in PBS as a control. 47

Finally, we generated a further stock of the 62 SARS-CoV-2 lineage B.1 virus in unbuffered saline in Vero cells and tested it against water at 3 pH 63 levels at chlorine levels of 1.56 -1.68 ppm. Firstly, emitted virus will be greatly diluted before this occurs, potentially below a 89 minimal infectious dose. In addition, if chlorinated water is directly viricidal against SARS-CoV-2, the 90 likelihood of infectious virus being transmitted in swimming pool water will be further lowered. 91

body_text.text: Demonstrating this may be important in increasing public confidence in returning to pools. Here we 92 demonstrate that inactivation of SARS-CoV-2 in chlorinated swimming pool water is dependent on 93 free chlorine and pH levels with increased inactivation at higher free chlorine and lower pH. We show 94 that 30 seconds contact time at RT with water of a pH of no more than 7.4 and free chlorine above 1.5 95 mg/l (ppm) resulted in at least a 3-log10 reduction in viral titre (Figure 1 ). These levels are within the 96 recommendations for swimming pools in the UK of at least 1.5 ppm free chlorine, although pH 97 guidelines allow a pH of 7.0-7.6 and we found here that some residual virus was detected after 98 treatment with water above pH7.4 even when at least 1.5 ppm free chlorine was present. 99 A limitation of this study is that we did not test survival of SARS-CoV-2 contained within mucus or 100 saliva mixed with swimming pool water. Further we were only able to test reduction of a virus stock 101 with infectivity around 10 4 TCID50/ml due to the limited replication of SARS-CoV-2 in the laboratory 102 and the need use a minimal volume of virus material during testing. FIGREF0.text: Exposure to chlorinated water inactivates SARS-CoV-2. Water samples taken from a 69 swimming pool were modified in the laboratory to a range of pH and free chlorine values. A known 70 amount of infectious SARS-CoV-2 was added to duplicate water samples in a volume of 1 ml, incubated 71 for 30 seconds at RT and any remaining infectious virus then titrated by TCID50 on Vero cells. Residual 72 virus titres are shown as the mean and SD of duplicate TCID50/ml values. Successive experiments were 73 performed with varying free chlorine levels (a), varying pH (b), a range of both pH and free chlorine 74 levels (c), and an independent preparation of virus at a range of pH and chlorine levels (d). A PBS 75 control was included in each experiment to validate the infectivity of the virus input. Lower pH and 76 higher free chlorine levels resulted in greater inactivation of SARS-CoV-2. A pH of no more than 7.4 77 and free chlorine above 1.5 parts per million (ppm) resulted in at least a 3-log10 reduction in viral titre. Discussion 79 Swimming pools have reopened in the UK as of April 12 th 2021 and therefore present locations of 80 possible COVID-19 transmission. The likelihood of transmission events occurring in shared areas such 81 as changing rooms can be minimised with social distancing and hygiene measures around the pool but 82 different variables affect any risk associated with time spent in the water. Chlorination of swimming 83 pool water has been used for decades to mitigate any onwards transmission of pathogens between 84 swimmers. However, since the causative agent of COVID-19, the betacoronavirus named SARS-CoV-2, 85 only emerged in late 2019, inactivation of SARS-CoV-2 by chlorinated water has not yet been directly 86 demonstrated. The route by which any residual virus in swimming pool water 106 might infect another swimmer is not clear. SARS-CoV-2 is transmitted in the air and also by direct 107inoculation. There is also a potential faecal-oral route of transmission for SARS-CoV-2 (Guo et al., 108 2021). Our findings on the susceptibility of SARS-CoV-2 to inactivation by swimming pool water 109 underscore the importance for those who maintain swimming pools to adhere to UK guidelines for 110 chlorination, and this should give confidence in the safety of bathers when in the water. Finally, we 111 stress that swimmers should continue to adhere to locally recommended social distancing rules both 112 in and out of the water. Figure  128 1d. Chlorine levels of the water samples were increased by addition of sodium hypochlorite and pH 129 was increased by addition of sodium carbonate or decreased using sodium bisulphate before 130 retesting. Inactivation experiments were performed within 30 minutes of water sample preparation 131 to minimise decay of chlorine levels. 132

Treatment of SARS-CoV-2 with water samples was carried out as described in the text. In short 10ul of 134 virus stock was added to 990ul of water sample, incubated for 30 seconds at RT before addition of 135 110ul of 10X MEM. Titration of residual virus was performed by TCID50 assay on Vero cells using 136 cytopathic effect as the readout for infectious virus. In short, a half-log10 dilution series of each sample 137 was performed and 4 replicates of each dilution transferred to 96-well plates of Vero cells, incubated 138 for 1 hr at 37°C, 5% CO2 and replaced with cell growth medium. After 4 days, cells were stained with 139 crystal violet and scored for either an intact, stained cell sheet or the absence of cells due to virus-140 induced cytopathic effect. For each condition, the Spearman-Karber method was used to calculate the 141 50% tissue culture infectious dose (TCID50) of the residual virus.
